channel.title: How do i edit this

item.title: How do i edit this
item.dc:creator: @yong_min yong min
item.description:
@yong_min wrote:

In your Formulae class, you can define how much XP is given per bar.

	public static int getSmithingExp(int barID, int barCount) {
		int[] exps = {13, 25, 37, 50, 83, 74};
		int type = getBarType(barID);
		if(type < 0) {
			return 0;
		}
		return exps[type] * barCount;
	}

@Mario, the only actual smithing EXP that is handled via XML is the smelting EXP. The ‘ItemSmithingDef’ identifies how many bars are needed/used to create the item, then it is multiplied by the EXP per bar via the Formulae class.

@Pandemicpk, if you are wanting to alter the EXP for smelting, that is done in the ‘ItemSmeltingDef’ XML file. If you are wanting to alter the actual item smithing, then alter it in the Formulae class.

For example:

[b]Item:[/b] Rune 2-handed Sword [b]Bars Needed:[/b] 3 [b]EXP per Bar:[/b] 74 [b]Given EXP:[/b] (74 * 3) * EXP Multiplier

If the EXP Multiplier is 30.0x for example, the EXP given for smithing a Rune 2-handed Sword will be: (74 * 3) * 30 = 6,660

6,660 EXP is given if you smith a Rune 2-handed Sword with a EXP Multiplier of 30.0

Hopefully, this is clear enough for you to understand, if not, sorry!

[EDIT] I didn’t see you are looking for Prayer EXP too. To alter the amount of EXP given for each bone, open up your InvActionHandler class, and find:

else if(item.getDef().getCommand().equalsIgnoreCase("bury")) {

Now if you look further down within the switch, you will see the different cases for each bone ID.

Let’s look at the Dragon Bones as an example:

owner.incExp(5, 600, true, true);

The 5 is representing the skill ID, in this case, Prayer. The 600 identifies the EXP amount to be given for burying that type of bone. The first ‘true’ determines whether or not by burying that bone it will give the player any Fatigue, and the last ‘true’ determines whether or not the EXP (600) should be multiplied by the EXP Multiplier.

In simpler terms, by burying a Dragon Bone, the EXP given is as follows:

[b]Bone Type:[/b] Dragon Bones [b]EXP per Bone:[/b] 600 [b]Uses Fatigue?[/b] Yes [b]Multiplied EXP?[/b] Yes [b]Total EXP Given:[/b] 600 * EXP Multiplier

So sticking with 30.0x as our EXP Multiplier, the total amount of EXP given for Dragon Bones will be: 600 * 30 = 18,000

Again, hopefully this is understandable, if not, again, sorry!
